Title: Amygdalo-cortical projections in the monkey (Macaca fascicularis)
Abstract:
Amygdalo-cortical projections were analyzed in the macaque monkey (Macaca fascicularis) in a series of experiments in
which 3H-amino acids were injected into each of the major divisions of the amygdaloid complex and the anterogradely
transported label was demonstrated autoradiographically. Projections to widespread regions of frontal, insular, temporal, and
occipital cortices have been observed. The heaviest projections to frontal cortex terminated in medial and orbital regions
which included areas 24, 25, and 32 on the medial surface and areas 14, 13a, and 12 on the orbital surface. Lighter projections
were also seen in areas 45, 46, 6, 9, and 10. The heaviest projection to the insula terminated in the agranular insular cortex with
a decreasing gradient of innervation to the more caudally placed dysgranular and granular insular areas. The projection to this
region continues around the dorsal limiting sulcus to terminate in the somatosensory fields 3, 1-2, and SII. Essentially all major
divisions of the temporal neocortex receive a projection from the amygdaloid complex with the most prominent projections
ending in the cortex of the temporal pole (area TG) and the perirhinal cortex. The entire rostrocaudal extent of the
inferotemporal cortex (areas TE and TEO) is also in receipt of an amygdaloid projection. While the rostral superior temporal
gyrus (area TA) is heavily labeled in several of the experiments (with light labeling continuing into AI and adjacent auditory
association regions) there was little indication of labeling in the caudal reaches of area TA. There was a surprisingly strong
projection to prestriate regions of the occipital lobe and, in at least one case, clear-cut labeling in areas OB and 17. Labeling in
the parietal cortex was primarily observed in the depths of the intraparietal sulcus. In all cortical fields, label was heaviest at
the border between layers I and II and in some regions layers V and VI also had above background levels of silver grains.

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Region_Parcellation: Amygdala, frontal cortex, insula, temporal cortex
@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation:
" In order to illustrate the projections to large areas of the cortex, two unfolded surface maps were constructed (Fig. 3), one for the frontal cortex, and one for the insular and temporal cortex, and the projections were transferred onto one or both maps.
The maps were constructed according to the procedure by 
Van Essen and Maunsell (`80). " (pp. 467-468)
@BrainMaps_Delineation.Comments: In Fig. 1 both the injections and the amygdalar delineations are shown.

@InterMapRelations.Comments: It is nowhere stated from which parcellation scheme area EC (entorhinal cortex) is adopted, but it seems quite clear that it is identical with the entorhinal cortex of AIC87, because (i) they have the same location, and (ii) D.G. Amaral is author of both papers.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The terminology used for the fields of the temporal lobe is based, for the most part, on the designations of Bonin and Bailey ('47), except for the areas immediately to the rhinal sulcus; these are termed area 35 and 36, after the perirhinal and ectorhinal fields of Brodmann ('09)." (p. 468)
@InterMapRelations.Comments:
Indeed, it is stated that area 36 of AP84 is identical with area 36 of B09, but Brodmann said that there is no area 36 in the monkey brain.
Because of that we assumed that area 36 of AP84 is identical with area 36 of AIC87, because (i) they have the same location, and (ii) D.G. Amaral is an author of both papers.

@InterMapRelations.Comments:
The desription of the location of area TA2 is not stated clearly, so you can not  ambigously say that area TA2 of BB47 is a subpart of area TA of BB47. Only the same abbreviation gives you a hint that area TA of BB47 contains area TA2 of AP84.
Because of that area TA , as delineated here, is much more smaller than area TA of BB47 and consequently is a subpart of BB47's area TA.
Because area TE is located in the immediate vicinity of area TA2, it is actual not clear, if it has the same extension as area TE of BB47.

"The terminology for the insular region is based primarily on the maps published by Jones and Burton ('76; Burton and Jones, '76) and is very similar to that used in the recent study by Mesulam and Mufson ('82). Briefly, the insula itself is divided, from rostral to caudal, into agranular, dysgranular, and granular fields. One slight difference in our parcellation from previously published maps is that we consider that a "tail" of the agranular insular area extends further caudally in the fundus of the inferior limiting sulcus than has been noted by the other authors. ...It may be noted that the ventral part of the agranular insular area, as delineated here, probably corresponds to the juxtallocortical area of Jones and Burton, and to the area designated as the agranular periallocortical part of the orbitofrontal cortex (OFa-p) by Mesulam and Mufson ('82)." (p. 468)
@InterMapRelations.Comments:
As stated textually, the agranular insular area of AP84 is larger than the area delineated by JB76 and MM82a and contains  area J (juxtallocortical area) of JB76 and area OFa-p of MM82a. 
Because both JB76-J and MM82a-OFa-p are located directly rostroventrally  to the agranular insular cortex (JB76: Fig. 2, p. 200; MM82a:Fig. 2, p. 6), the rostral border of this insular cortex in AP84 ,logically consistent,  has to lie more rostral than in MM82a and JB76, respectively.
It is also said that a part " of the agranular insular area extends further caudally in the fundus of the inferior limiting sulcus than has been noted by the other authors " (p. 468). As a result of that the caudal border of the agranular insular cortex in AP84 is located more caudally than in JB76 and MM82a, respectively.
Shortly summarized, the agranular insular cortex of AP84 has in contrast to JB76 and MM82a a larger extension in rostrally and caudally direction. Because the dysgranular insular cortex of JB76 and MM82a is located in the caudally and dorsocaudally, respectively,  vicinity of the agranular cortex,  AP84-Ia overlaps with JB76-Id and MM82a-Idg. If AP84-Ia contains JB76-J and MM82a-OFa-p it is logically consistent, on the condition that the other borders are equal, that AP84-Ia also contains JB76-Ia and MM82a-Ia-p.  Seeing that the border between the dysgranular and granular insular is not affected by the modifications of AP84's parcellation scheme, AP84-Ig has to be identical with JB76-Ig and MM82a-Ig.

Because the dysgranular insular cortex of JB76 and MM82a is located in the caudally and dorsocaudally, respectively,  vicinity of the agranular cortex,  AP84-Ia overlaps with JB76-Id and MM82a-Idg. If AP84-Ia contains JB76-J and MM82a-OFa-p it is logically consistent, on the condition that the other borders are equal, that AP84-Ia also contains JB76-Ia and MM82a-Ia-p.  Seeing that the border between the dysgranular and granular insular is not affected by the modifications of AP84's parcellation scheme, AP84-Ig has to be identical with JB76-Ig and MM82a-Ig.

It is nowhere stated from which parcellation scheme area EN (endopiriform nucleus) is adopted, but it seems quite clear that it is identical with the EN of IAC87b, because (i) they have the same location, and (ii) D.G. Amaral is author of both papers.

It is not stated from which parcellation scheme the description of the amygdaloid complex has been adopted, but it is quite probable that it equals the map of AP84, because (i) they have approximately the same location, (ii) the same abbreviations, and (iii) the authors of both papers are the same.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The terminology used for the fields of the temporal lobe is based, for the most part, on the designations of Bonin and Bailey ('47), except for the areas immediately lateral to the rhinal sulcus; these are termed areas 35 and 36, after the peririnal and ectorhinal fields of Brodmann ('09). Briefly, area TG occupies the temporal pole, while areas TA and TE occupy the superior , and middle and inferior temporal gyri, respectively. Caudal to the entorhinal cortex of the hippocampal formation are areas TF and TF which, taken together, make up the parahippocampal gyrus. The area which we have designated as area TE corresponds approximately to the combined areas Ts1, Ts2, and Ts3 of Pandya and Seltzer ('73) and Galaburda and Pandya ('83). We recognized an additional subfield in the widened fundus of the superior temporal sulcus which appeared clearly different from any of the fields of TA and TE, which we designated area TA2. Caudal to area TE are the temporal and occipital areas associated with the visual system, including areas TEO, MT, OA, OB, and 17." (p. 468)
"The terminology for the insular region is based primarily on the maps published by Jones and Burton ('76) and is very similar to that used in the recent study by Mesulam and Mufson ('82)"

"For the frontal cortex, we have adopted the subdivisions and terminology proposed by Walker ('40), though we have made certain modifications in order that his scheme be more compatible with the maps of Brodmann ('09), and with the terminology used previously in the rat and cat (Krettek and Price, '78). ... Price is an author of both papers.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "For the frontal cortex, we have adopted the subdivisions and terminology proposed by Walker ('40), though we have made certain modifications in order that his scheme be more compatible with the maps of Brodmann ('09), and with the terminology used previously in the rat and cat (Krettek and Price, '78). In particular, that portion of Walker's area 24 located just ventral to the genu of the corpus callosum is here identified as area 25, which has been labeled the infralimbic area by Brodmann ('09). The portion of Walker's area 25 located rostrally, on the medial surface, is clearly a more laminated cortex than infralimbic cortex and is here identified as area 32, or by Brodmann's term, the prelimbic area." (p. 468)

"The terminology for the insular region is based primarily on the maps published by Jones and Burton ('76; Burton and Jones, '76) and is very similar to that used in the recent study by Mesulam and Mufson ('82). Briefly, the insula itself is divided, from rostral to caudal, into agranular, dysgranular, and granular fields. One slight difference in our parcellation from previously published maps is that we consider that a "tail" of the agranular insular area extends further caudally in the fundus of the inferior limiting sulcus than has been noted by the other authors. ...It may be noted that the ventral part of the agranular insular area, as delineated here, probably corresponds to the juxtallocortical area of Jones and Burton, and to the area designated as the agranular periallocortical part of the orbitofrontal cortex (OFa-p) by Mesulam and Mufson ('82)." (p. 468)
@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments:
As stated textually, the agranular insular area of AP84 is larger than the area delineated by JB76 and MM82a and contains  area J (juxtallocortical area) of JB76 and area OFa-p of MM82a. 
Because both JB76-J and MM82a-OFa-p are located directly rostroventrally  to the agranular insular cortex (JB76: Fig. 2, p. 200; MM82a:Fig. 2, p. 6), the rostral border of this insular cortex in AP84 ,logically consistent,  has to lie more rostral than in MM82a and JB76, respectively.
It is also said that a part " of the agranular insular area extends further caudally in the fundus of the inferior limiting sulcus than has been noted by the other authors " (p. 468). As a result of that the caudal border of the agranular insular cortex in AP84 is located more caudally than in JB76 and MM82a, respectively.
Shortly summarized, the agranular insular cortex of AP84 has in contrast to JB76 and MM82a a larger extension in rostrally and caudally direction. Because the dysgranular insular cortex of JB76 and MM82a is located in the caudally and dorsocaudally, respectively,  vicinity of the agranular cortex,  AP84-Ia overlaps with JB76-Id and MM82a-Idg. If AP84-Ia contains JB76-J and MM82a-OFa-p it is logically consistent, on the condition that the other borders are equal, that AP84-Ia also contains JB76-Ia and MM82a-Ia-p.  Seeing that the border between the dysgranular and granular insular is not affected by the modifications of AP84's parcellation scheme, AP84-Ig has to be identical with JB76-Ig and MM82a-Ig.

@InterMapRelations_clean.Citation: "The terminology used for the fields of the temporal lobe is based, for the most part, on the designations of Bonin and Bailey ('47), except for the areas immediately lateral to the rhinal sulcus; these are termed areas 35 and 36, after the peririnal and ectorhinal fields of Brodmann ('09). Briefly, area TG occupies the temporal pole, while areas TA and TE occupy the superior , and middle and inferior temporal gyri, respectively. Caudal to the entorhinal cortex of the hippocampal formation are areas TF and TF which, taken together, make up the parahippocampal gyrus. The area which we have designated as area TE corresponds approximately to the combined areas Ts1, Ts2, and Ts3 of Pandya and Seltzer ('73) and Galaburda and Pandya ('83). We recognized an additional subfield in the widened fundus of the superior temporal sulcus which appeared clearly different from any of the fields of TA and TE, which we designated area TA2. Caudal to area TE are the temporal and occipital areas associated with the visual system, including areas TEO, MT, OA, OB, and 17." (p. 468)

"For the frontal cortex, we have adopted the subdivisions and terminology proposed by Walker ('40), though we have made certain modifications in order that his scheme be more compatible with the maps of Brodmann ('09), and with the terminology used previously in the rat and cat (Krettek and Price, '78). ... The orbital surface is occupied by Walker's areas 12 and 14 on the ventrolateral and ventromedial corners of the lobe, respectively, and between these by area 13 caudally and area 11 rostrally. An additional small area along the medial bank of the medial orbital sulcus has both cytoarchitectonic and connectional differences from the rest of area 13; we have designated this region area 13a to differentiate it from the rest of area 13." (p. 468)

It is not clearly stated, from which parcellation scheme area 24 is adopted, but it seems that this rostral portion of the cingulate gyrus is identical with B09's area 24, because (i) they have approximately the same location, and (ii) B09 has been already cited in this paper.

Price is an author of both papers.

@InterMapRelations_clean.Citation: "For the frontal cortex, we have adopted the subdivisions and terminology proposed by Walker ('40), though we have made certain modifications in order that his scheme be more compatible with the maps of Brodmann ('09), and with the terminology used previously in the rat and cat (Krettek and Price, '78). In particular, that portion of Walker's area 24 located just ventral to the genu of the corpus callosum is here identified as area 25, which has been labeled the infralimbic area by Brodmann ('09). The portion of Walker's area 25 located rostrally, on the medial surface, is clearly a more laminated cortex than infralimbic cortex and is here identified as area 32, or by Brodmann's term, the prelimbic area." (p. 468)

"For the frontal cortex, we have adopted the subdivisions and terminology proposed by Walker ('40), though we have made certain modifications in order that his scheme be more compatible with the maps of Brodmann ('09), and with the terminology used previously in the rat and cat (Krettek and Price, '78). In particular, that portion of Walker's area 24 located just ventral to the genu of the corpus callosum is here identified as area 25, which has been labeled the infralimbic area by Brodmann ('09). The portion of Walker's area 25 located rostrally, on the medial surface, is clearly a more laminated cortex than infralimbic cortex and is here identified as area 32, or by Brodmann's term, the prelimbic area." In particular, that portion of Walker's area 24 located just ventral to the genu of the corpus callosum is here identified as area 25, which has been labeled the infralimbic area by Brodmann ('09). The portion of Walker's area 25 located rostrally, on the medial surface, is clearly a more laminated cortex than infralimbic cortex and is here identified as area 32, or by Brodmann's term, the prelimbic area." (p. 468)

publication.title: Amygdalo-cortical projections in the monkey (Macaca fascicularis)
publication.abstract:
Amygdalo-cortical projections were analyzed in the macaque monkey (Macaca fascicularis) in a series of experiments in
which 3H-amino acids were injected into each of the major divisions of the amygdaloid complex and the anterogradely
transported label was demonstrated autoradiographically. Projections to widespread regions of frontal, insular, temporal, and
occipital cortices have been observed. The heaviest projections to frontal cortex terminated in medial and orbital regions
which included areas 24, 25, and 32 on the medial surface and areas 14, 13a, and 12 on the orbital surface. Lighter projections
were also seen in areas 45, 46, 6, 9, and 10. The heaviest projection to the insula terminated in the agranular insular cortex with
a decreasing gradient of innervation to the more caudally placed dysgranular and granular insular areas. The projection to this
region continues around the dorsal limiting sulcus to terminate in the somatosensory fields 3, 1-2, and SII. Essentially all major
divisions of the temporal neocortex receive a projection from the amygdaloid complex with the most prominent projections
ending in the cortex of the temporal pole (area TG) and the perirhinal cortex. The entire rostrocaudal extent of the
inferotemporal cortex (areas TE and TEO) is also in receipt of an amygdaloid projection. While the rostral superior temporal
gyrus (area TA) is heavily labeled in several of the experiments (with light labeling continuing into AI and adjacent auditory
association regions) there was little indication of labeling in the caudal reaches of area TA. There was a surprisingly strong
projection to prestriate regions of the occipital lobe and, in at least one case, clear-cut labeling in areas OB and 17. Labeling in
the parietal cortex was primarily observed in the depths of the intraparietal sulcus. In all cortical fields, label was heaviest at
the border between layers I and II and in some regions layers V and VI also had above background levels of silver grains.
